props.children:
## Iter8 Tutorial 1 

### Verifying Success Metrics

We will walk through an **application deployment scenario**. Before we can promote our application to production, we first need to ensure that our performance and error rate tolerances are satisfied.

### Activities

- **[Deploy the application](#kui-link-ad06f8b4-bd31-40cf-98af-e6417f306a1a)** *blank* We use a hello world app.
- **[Start the Iter8 experiment](#kui-link-8747f6df-3926-4e90-a75b-febced2dd1cd)** *blank* Define **success metrics**, and initiate an *Iter8 Experiment*. Iter8 will drive load, and track the success metrics for us.
- **Monitor progress** *minor* Live views help you track the experiment.
- **[Understand Iter8's recommendation](#kui-link-94e4c2c8-bd90-4467-b569-610510ed1269)** *blank* When the evaluation period ends and the success metrics have been met, Iter8 marks the Experiment as successful.
- **Promote the candidate** *minor* If you are content with the results of the Experiment, you may promote the candidate to production.

# Iterate Example Application 1

- [Deploy the baseline and candidate applications](#kui-link-096628c3-f3e7-4a25-903e-663d6e63f216)
- [Start the Iter8 Experiment](#kui-link-2c3467d5-624c-41d6-bbe8-070609dff20c)
- [Monitor the Progress of the Experiment](#kui-link-e29c2fb4-7098-4641-a121-02b42a1ea26a)

### Use case details
Your application is deployed to your production Kubernetes environment.
Subequent development has resulted in a new version of the application.
It has passed its unit and functional test cases. Is it ready to deploy to production? 

Experience shows that passing unit and functional tests does not mean that a new version will meet our expected service level objectives such as acceptable error rate or mean request latency.

To gain confidence, we dark launch the application and use Iter8 to run an *experiment* on it.

Iter8 measures key metrics and determines with statistical confidence if your desired service level objectives are met.

props.children:
### Use Case Details
You have application is deployed to a production Kubernetes environment.
Subequent development has resulted in a new version of the application.
It has passed its unit and functional test cases.
Is it ready to deploy to production?
For example, by modifying the application manifest (change the image tag) and reapplying it.
Experience shows, however, that new versions often don't meet our expected service level objectives such as acceptable error rate or mean request latency.
To gain confidence, we dark launch the applicatiomn and use Iter8 to run an *experiment* on it.
Iter8 measures key metrics and determines with statistical confidence if your desired service level objectives are met.

> Prerequisites and Objectives
>
> 1) Requires that your cluster has [Iter8](https://iter8.tools) provisioned.
> 2) This scenario does *not* require [Istio](https://istio.io/) support.
> 3) Instead, to keep things simple, we will use `kubectl apply` to roll out out the upgrade.
>
> To learn how Iter8 can leverage [Istio](https://istio.io) or [KNative](https://knative.dev), consult `Iter8 Tutorial 2`. There, you will learn how `Iter8` can carry out an incremental rollout of an upgrade, ensuring that the rollout proceeds only if success metrics are achieved.
​

props.children:
> This demo assumes that you are running in a k8s cluster with no istio support and the way you carry out your upgrades is by leveraging `kubectl apply` which will progressively promote one version over the other. In case you are leverage `istio` or `knative` demos `1` and `2` show how to leverage `iter8` in combination with `istio` and `knative` to carry out upgrades.
​

First, we use `kubectl apply` to deploy the first version of our sample application. Then, we use `curl` to verify that it is up and running.

---
# Source: deploy/templates/services.yaml
apiVersion: v1
kind: Service
metadata:
  name: hello-candidate
  labels:
    app.kubernetes.io/managed-by: Iter8
    app.kubernetes.io/name: hello
    app.kubernetes.io/track: candidate
spec:
  type: ClusterIP
  ports:
  -
    port: 8080
  selector:
    app.kubernetes.io/name: hello
    app.kubernetes.io/track: candidate
---
# Source: deploy/templates/deployments.yaml
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  name: hello-candidate
  labels:
    app.kubernetes.io/managed-by: Iter8
    app.kubernetes.io/name: hello
    app.kubernetes.io/track: candidate
spec:
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app.kubernetes.io/name: hello
      app.kubernetes.io/track: candidate
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        app.kubernetes.io/name: hello
        app.kubernetes.io/track: candidate
    spec:
      containers:
      - name: hello
        image: 'gcr.io/google-samples/hello-app:2.0'
        ports:
        - containerPort: 8080

## **Step 2**   Start the Iter8 experiment We would like to promote `hello-candidate` to production, provided that it satisfies a series of service level objectives (SLOs). In this case, we are focus on the metrics below, but these can be any in-built or *user-defined* metrics.

1. Mean latency for application requests should be < **500** 2. 95th percentile latency should be less than **1000** 3. Error rate to should be less than **0.01**

props.children:
## **Step 2**   Start the Iter8 Experiment We would like to promote `hello-canidate` to production, given that it satisfies a series of SLOs(service level objectives). In this case we are focussing on the metrics below, but these can be any in-built or *user-definied* metrics.

1. Mean latency rate for the application should be > x 2. Median latency rate for the application should be > x 3. Number of 404's over a period of x time should be less than y

The snippet below shows the part of the experiment yaml that describes the criteria in order for the experiment to be marked success. TODO: May be the snippet can be a hyperlink that opens in the side window

In order to do that,  we run an **Iter8 experiment**. Our experiment will generate traffic to the *hello-candidate* version of the application and will monitor the metrics that get generated as a result of this traffic. If the metrics satisfy the SLOs defined then we can go ahead and promote this version.

templates.data:
---
# Source: deploy/charts/deploy/templates/experiment.yaml
apiVersion: iter8.tools/v2alpha2
kind: Experiment
metadata:
  # the sha256sum suffix based on candidate is useful; it ensures that 
  # a new experiment is generated whenever the candidate version is updated 
  # (for example, by CD pipeline)
  name: hello-experiment
spec:
  # target should uniquely identify the application under experimentation
  target: hello
  strategy:
    # this is an SLO validation experiment
    testingPattern: Conformance
    actions:
      start:
      # ensure candidate service and deployment of the application are available
      - task: common/readiness 
        with:
          objRefs:
          - kind: Service
            name: hello-candidate
            namespace: default
          - kind: Deployment
            name: hello-candidate
            namespace: default
            waitFor: condition=available
      # collect Iter8's built-in metrics
      - task: metrics/collect
        with:
          time: "20s"
          versions:
          - name: new-version # this name must match the name of a version in versionInfo
            url: "http://hello-candidate.default:8080"
            qps: 8
  criteria:
    requestCount: iter8-system/request-count
    indicators:
    - iter8-system/error-count
    # service-level objectives (SLOs) that need to be satisfied by the new version
    # in order for it to be considered a winner
    objectives:
    - metric: iter8-system/mean-latency
      upperLimit: "500"
    - metric: iter8-system/error-rate
      upperLimit: "0.01"
    - metric: iter8-system/latency-95th-percentile
      upperLimit: "1000"
  duration:
    intervalSeconds: 1
    iterationsPerLoop: 1
  versionInfo:
    baseline:
      name: new-version

startEvent.command: k apply -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/kalantar/iter8/cil/samples/cil/first-exp/experiment.yaml

completeEvent.command: k apply -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/kalantar/iter8/cil/samples/cil/first-exp/experiment.yaml

startEvent.command: kubectl get Experiment.v2alpha2.iter8.tools -n staging-asood---us-ibm-com hello-experiment -o yaml

completeEvent.command: kubectl get Experiment.v2alpha2.iter8.tools -n staging-asood---us-ibm-com hello-experiment -o yaml

templates.data:
---
# Source: deploy/charts/deploy/templates/experiment.yaml
apiVersion: iter8.tools/v2alpha2
kind: Experiment
metadata:
  # the sha256sum suffix based on candidate is useful; it ensures that 
  # a new experiment is generated whenever the candidate version is updated 
  # (for example, by CD pipeline)
  name: hello-experiment
spec:
  # target should uniquely identify the application under experimentation
  target: hello
  strategy:
    # this is an SLO validation experiment
    testingPattern: Conformance
    actions:
      start:
      # ensure candidate service and deployment of the application are available
      - task: common/readiness 
        with:
          objRefs:
          - kind: Service
            name: hello-candidate
            namespace: default
          - kind: Deployment
            name: hello-candidate
            namespace: default
            waitFor: condition=available
      # collect Iter8's built-in metrics
      - task: metrics/collect
        with:
          time: "20s"
          versions:
          - name: new-version # this name must match the name of a version in versionInfo
            url: "http://hello-candidate.default:8080"
            qps: 8
  criteria:
    requestCount: iter8-system/request-count
    indicators:
    - iter8-system/error-count
    # service-level objectives (SLOs) that need to be satisfied by the new version
    # in order for it to be considered a winner
    objectives:
    - metric: iter8-system/mean-latency
      upperLimit: "500"
    - metric: iter8-system/error-rate
      upperLimit: "0.01"
    - metric: iter8-system/latency-95th-percentile
      upperLimit: "1000"
  duration:
    intervalSeconds: 1
    iterationsPerLoop: 1
  versionInfo:
    baseline:
      name: new-version

props.children: > As part of an **experiment definition**, Iter8 lets you define a set of **objectives** and **indicators**. If you click to expand the "Show experiment.yaml" above, you will see that this experiment defines three metrics under criteria: mean-latency, error-rate, and latency-95th-percentile. In addition, you can specify the  bounds of acceptable values for each metric. For example, this experiment specifies a maximum mean-latency of 500 milliseconds.

This notebook automatically watches the progress of `kubectl` commands. See above. In your terminal, you may  tack the status of a running experiment using `kubectl get experiment hello-experiment --watch`

### Tracking the Ongoing Status of your Experiment

In this notebook, the table above will present a live traffic light. When the experiment is done, the traffic light will turn either green (if successful) or red (if the experiment failed).

In your terminal, you may  tack the status of a running experiment via: 
```sh
kubectl get experiment hello-experiment --watch
```

props.children:
##  **Step 4**    Understanding Iter8's recommendation

An experiment is deemed finished when it has run through all the iterations or failed. At the end of experiment the status of the experiment is set to **Completed**. The message will indicate whether or not it has **Failed**. If it completes without failure, Iter8 will recommend whether or not the version should be promoted or not depending on whether or not it satisfied the requred SLOs. 

You can execute the below command to get details of the observed metrics and which satisfied their objectives.

props.children:
##  **Step 4**    Understanding the results of the experiment

An experiment is deemed finished when it has run through all the iterations. At the end of experiment the status of the experiment is set as either **Completed** or **Failed** depending on whether the experiment was able to satisfy the expected SLOs. More details [here](www.google.com/open_in_sidebar)

You can execute the below command to get the results of the experiment.

##  **Step 5**   Optionally, promote the candidate version

Once an experiment has finished, you can go ahead and promote this candidate. This can be done using any existing delivery pipeline, by applying the manifest (`kubectl apply -f <yaml for the latest candidate>`), or by using a *task* specified in the Iter8 experiment. Iter8 provides a facility to execute tasks when the experiment finishes. For example, the following task might be used. See, for example, [this](https://iter8.tools/0.7/reference/tasks/common-bash/) task.

##  **Step 5**   Optionally, promoting the candidate

Once an experiment has finished, you can go ahead and promote this candidate. This can be simply done by applying using in-built `kubectl apply -f <yaml for the latest candidate>` or can be done using **in-built** iter8 mechanics. As a part of defining the experiment, you can also define the **action** that should happen given the experiment is completed successfully.
